comments:
The help was installed as an infocenter on a server machine (Windows 2000 
server) at port 8081. The client was configured with the hostname (or IP 
address) of the server and the port number. When the client tried to access the 
help on the server, an exception is thrown. I think it's because of the way 
intranet access is set up - users need to enter a userid and password in 
order to access websites on their intranet and eclipse's help cannot handle 
that. 

Here is the exception and stack trace:

org.eclipse.core.runtime.CoreException: Application server could not start, 
because it could not open port 8081.
	at java.lang.Throwable.<init>(Throwable.java)
	at java.lang.Throwable.<init>(Throwable.java:66)
	at org.eclipse.core.runtime.CoreException.<init>(CoreException.java:35)
	at org.eclipse.tomcat.internal.TomcatAppServer.start
(TomcatAppServer.java:165)

(AppserverPlugin.java:171)

(WebappManager.java:50)

(ActionContributionItem.java:72)
	at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.EventTable.sendEvent(EventTable.java)
	at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Widget.sendEvent(Widget.java:840)

	at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.main(Main.java:583)

This is not supported scenario, or intended use of help server preference page.
The exception has nothing to do with remote server or password it requires.  
The value set for host was simply invalid (not any of local IP interfaces).

The preference page is for configuring intenral application server used 
internally by help sytem as stated on the page.
The host name or IP address is that of local machine not remote server.
The port number is port for server to listen on, not another server to connect 
to.

In 2.1.x providing invalid local host name is not detected and despite 
internal server failing to start, web browser was launched.
In 3.0 this has been fixed and the browser does not open when there is a 
problem with starting local appserver.


If you run local online help and F1, your product should include help plugins 
and things work out of the box.
If you do not wish to run local online help and F1, you do not need to use 
help plug-ins on the client.  Help can be run in the infocenter scenario, and 
on the client just add an action to the menu that will open a browser to the 
infocenter.
If you require a solution where help system runs locally to provide F1, and it 
is not used to view online help, but it IS used to open a browsrer, that is 
nothing we considered so far.  You can request this by openning an enhancement 
(feature request) here in bugzilla.

traces.message: Application server could not start,  because it could not open port 8081.
